questionList.questionText:
A 32-year-old man with substance use disorder is brought to the emergency department.  The patient was found by a friend on the floor of his apartment with a pool of urine around him.  He has been previously hospitalized for alcohol intoxication.  The patient is confused, not oriented to time or place, and does not recall recent events.  Temperature is 37.3 C (99.1 F), blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg, pulse is 67/min, and respirations are 12/min.  He is drowsy and moves all his extremities.  The pupils are small.  Skin is mottled over the upper back, buttocks, and posterior thighs.  Cardiopulmonary examination is normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Laboratory findings are the following:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin15.8 g/dL
    Platelets160,000/mm3
    Leukocytes13,000/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium136 mEq/L
    Potassium6.1 mEq/L
    Creatinine1.1 mg/dL
    Calcium7.5 mg/dL
    Glucose90 mg/dL
Liver function studies
    Albumin4.0 g/dL
    Total bilirubin1.1 mg/dL
    Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)262 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)189 U/L
Blood, plasma, and serum
    Phosphorus, inorganic5.5 mg/dL

Urine toxicology screen is positive for opioids.  Over the next 2 days, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Rhabdomyolysis

Etiology

Skeletal muscle lysis/necrosis due to:

  • Crush injury or prolonged immobilization
  • Intense muscle activity (eg, seizure, exertion)
  • Drug/medication toxicity (eg, statins)

Clinical features

  • Muscle pain & weakness
  • Dark urine (myoglobinuria/pigmenturia)
  • + Blood on urinalysis & no RBCs on microscopy
  • ↑ Serum K & PO4, ↓ serum Ca, ↑ AST > ALT
  • Acute kidney injury

Diagnosis

  • Serum creatine kinase >1,000 U/L
  • Consistent clinical features

Management

  • Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation
  • Sodium bicarbonate in some cases

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; RBCs = red blood cells.

This patient, who has a history of substance use (opioid, alcohol) and was found down by a friend, has laboratory findings consistent with rhabdomyolysis and is at greatest risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI).  Rhabdomyolysis results from large-scale skeletal muscle necrosis via mechanisms that include crush injury, ischemic injury, overexertion, and direct myocyte toxicity.  Opioids and other CNS depressants (eg, ethanol, benzodiazepines) can cause rhabdomyolysis by inducing impaired consciousness with prolonged immobilization and ischemic compression of dependent areas of skeletal muscle (eg, mottled skin over back, buttocks, and posterior thighs).

AKI in rhabdomyolysis predominantly results from decreased renal perfusion (due to intravascular volume depletion from shifting of fluid into damaged muscle tissue) and direct renal tubular toxicity of heme pigments, which are contained in myoglobin proteins released from lysed muscle cells.  An increase in serum creatinine is often delayed from presentation but can be profound over the ensuing days.

Other laboratory abnormalities indicative of rhabdomyolysis (all of which are seen in this patient) include:

  • Hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia, which result from the release of these electrolytes from lysed muscle cells into the bloodstream. 
  • Hypocalcemia, which is often present due to deposition of calcium in damaged muscle tissue.
  • Moderate transaminase elevations, which characteristically show greater elevation in aspartate aminotransferase (AST) than alanine aminotransferase (ALT) due to relatively higher levels of AST in skeletal muscle.

(Choices B, C, and D)  Patients with chronic alcohol use are at an increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage (subdural hematoma), necrotizing fasciitis, and osmotic demyelination syndrome; however, AKI is more likely in this patient with history and laboratory findings consistent with rhabdomyolysis.  Osmotic demyelination syndrome, which results from rapid correction of hyponatremia, is particularly unlikely given that this patient's serum sodium is normal on presentation and will not require correction.

(Choice E)  Splenic infarction can occur due to embolic disease (eg, atrial fibrillation, infective endocarditis) or in the setting of myeloproliferative disease (eg, myelofibrosis).  It is unlikely to occur in this patient with no cardiac murmurs or rhythm abnormalities on physical examination and no hematologic abnormalities other than mild leukocytosis.

Educational objective:
Rhabdomyolysis can result from prolonged immobilization with ischemic compression of skeletal muscle, a scenario that may occur following ingestion of a CNS depressant (eg, opioids).  Affected patients commonly develop acute kidney injury due to decreased renal perfusion and direct renal tubular toxicity of heme pigment, which is contained in the myoglobin protein released from lysed skeletal muscle cells.

Patient Information

Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department

History

History of Present Illness:

  • developed fever and chills today

  • unremarkable

  • combined hormonal contraceptive

  • no known drug allergies

  • noncontributory

Psychosocial History:

  • no tobacco, alcohol, or recreational substance use
  • married, no children; works as an accountant

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
38.4 C
(101.1 F)		108/min20/min110/74
mm Hg		97%
on RA		170 cm
(5 ft 7 in)		72 kg
(159 lb)		24.9 kg/m2
  • Appearance: awake and alert but uncomfortable; grimaces and changes position frequently
  • Pulmonary: clear lung fields
  • Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmur
  • Abdominal: soft and nontender
  • Musculoskeletal: left costovertebral angle tenderness to percussion

Diagnostic Studies

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis: 5-mm calculus in the left midureter with dilation of the proximal ureter

Question: Which of the following is the strongest indication for urgent urology consultation in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has ureterolithiasis (eg, 5-mm ureteral stone on CT scan) that has been causing severe flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria for the past day.  Now, she has developed fever and chills and has costovertebral angle tenderness on examination.  These findings are concerning for urinary tract infection (eg, pyelonephritis) and possible sepsis.

Ureterolithiasis accompanied by infection requires urgent urology consultation because it can rapidly progress to severe sepsis and shock.  In addition to typical management with fluid resuscitation, pain control, and antiemetics, affected patients usually require intravenous antibiotics and urinary tract decompression (eg, ureteral stenting, percutaneous nephrostomy).  Other indications for urgent urology consultation in ureterolithiasis include acute kidney injury, refractory pain or vomiting, and anuria (which likely indicates complete obstruction).

(Choice B)  Hematuria (gross or microscopic) is present in most patients with symptomatic ureteral stones and is not an indication for urgent urology consultation.

(Choice C)  Acute renal colic is often associated with severe pain and vomiting.  Specialty intervention is warranted for refractory symptoms, but this patient has had only 2 episodes of vomiting; the presence of infection is of greater concern.

(Choice D)  Most stones ≤5 mm in diameter pass spontaneously with conservative management and do not require additional intervention.  Outpatient urology referral (rather than urgent consultation) may be warranted for stones >10 mm or for stones that do not pass within 4-6 weeks.

(Choice E)  Most patients with symptomatic ureterolithiasis have some degree of ureteral obstruction, which commonly causes both pain symptoms (eg, renal colic) and ureteral dilation on imaging.  However, in the absence of complete obstruction, infection, or acute kidney injury, ureteral dilation alone is not an indication for urgent urology consultation.

Educational objective:
Ureterolithiasis complicated by infection (eg, fever, chills) requires urgent urology consultation because it can rapidly progress from pyelonephritis to severe sepsis and shock.  Affected patients usually require intravenous antibiotics and urinary tract decompression.  Other indications for urgent urology consultation include acute kidney injury, refractory pain or vomiting, and anuria.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 34 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to sudden-onset cramps in the right lower abdomen, sweating, nausea, and 2 episodes of vomiting within the past 3 hours.  She has had some irregular contractions but no vaginal bleeding or leakage of fluid.  Fetal movement is normal.  The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and the patient has no chronic medical conditions.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg, and pulse is 102/min.  Fetal heart rate tracing shows a baseline of 155/min, moderate variability, multiple accelerations, and no decelerations.  Tocodynamometer demonstrates irregular contractions every 7-15 minutes.  There is mild tenderness to palpation over the right flank.  The uterus is nontender and the cervix is closed.  Urinalysis shows moderate blood but is negative for white blood cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites.  Laboratory studies show a hematocrit of 32%, leukocyte count of 14,000/mm3, and platelet count of 220,000/mm3.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This woman at 34 weeks gestation has sudden-onset right lower abdominal cramps with associated diaphoresis, nausea, and vomiting.  She has flank tenderness on examination and urinalysis reveals moderate hematuria.  This presentation is highly suggestive of renal colic secondary to nephrolithiasis.  In pregnancy, nephrolithiasis often occurs in the second and third trimesters due to progesterone-induced ureteral dilation and decreased peristalsis, which lead to urinary stasis.  In addition, pregnancy is associated with increased urinary calcium excretion.  These combined effects predispose pregnant women to stone formation.

Some patients with renal stones also experience irregular contractions due to the proximity of the uterus to the inflamed ureter because the uterus is sensitive and reactive to prostaglandins released from ongoing inflammation.  The diagnostic imaging of choice for evaluating abdominal pain in pregnancy, especially if renal stones are suspected, is renal and pelvic ultrasonography, rather than CT scan, to avoid unnecessary radiation to the fetus.

(Choices A and F)  This patient has no evidence of a urinary tract infection.  Urinalysis is negative for nitrites, leukocyte esterase, and white blood cells.  Although her serum white blood cell count is slightly elevated, this is very common in pregnancy and, without other indicators of infection (eg, fever), does not suggest an infectious process.  Neither antibiotics nor urine culture is the best next step in management.

(Choice B)  Preterm labor is regular, painful contractions leading to cervical change at <37 weeks gestation.  This patient has irregular contractions (every 7-15 minutes) without cervical change, along with a nontender uterus (ruling out intrauterine infection).  The tocodynamometer activity is related to pelvic inflammation, not preterm labor; therefore, uterine tocolytics are not indicated.

(Choice C)  Abdominal radiography is of limited utility in diagnosing renal stones because it detects only radiopaque stones, misses small stones (of any composition), and does not detect hydronephrosis.  Patient factors (obesity, constipation) can further decrease their sensitivity.  In addition, x-rays expose the fetus to small amounts of radiation.

(Choice D)  Coagulation studies would be indicated if disseminated intravascular coagulation secondary to placental abruption were suspected.  Placental abruption causes acute-onset vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, high-frequency contractions, and abnormalities on tocodynamic monitoring (eg, decelerations).

Educational objective:
Renal colic in pregnancy is associated with abdominal pain, flank tenderness, hematuria, and, often, irregular uterine contractions.  Ultrasonography is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal pain in pregnancy because it avoids radiation to the fetus.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to dyspnea, fatigue, poor appetite, and weight gain over the past 2 weeks.  The patient initially had only exertional dyspnea; however, over the last few days, he has been waking up breathless.  He also finds it difficult to open his eyes in the morning due to periorbital edema.  The patient has no known chronic medical conditions and takes no medications.  Blood pressure is 200/120 mm Hg and pulse is 100/min.  Physical examination shows anasarca with distended jugular veins while sitting upright.  Lung auscultation shows bibasilar crackles.  Urinalysis shows 1+ protein, no nitrite, trace leukocyte esterase, >50 red blood cells/hpf, red blood cell casts, and occasional white blood cells.  Which of the following is the primary contributor to this patient's edema?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has generalized edema with fluid accumulation in the lungs (eg, crackles), central veins (ie, jugular venous distension [JVD]), and systemic circulation (eg, weight gain).  Generalized edema can result from the following mechanisms:

  • Renal sodium retention:  Total body sodium and water retention lead to increased plasma volume.  Causes can be secondary to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) (ie, decreased effective arterial blood volume [EABV]) or primary (ie, direct renal injury) independent of the RAAS.

  • Altered capillary hemodynamics:  Fluid moves from the vascular space into the interstitium.  Causes include increased capillary hydrostatic pressure, decreased plasma oncotic pressure, and/or increased capillary permeability.

This patient's hematuria (with red blood cell casts) and severe hypertension suggest glomerulonephritis, which involves primary glomerular injury.  This leads to RAAS-independent sodium retention (exact mechanism unclear), which expands the plasma volume, thereby increasing capillary hydrostatic pressure and causing fluid movement into the interstitial space.  Because of loss of functional nephrons, a reduced glomerular filtration rate further contributes to edema (ie, similar to chronic kidney disease).

(Choice A)  Increased urinary protein excretion (eg, albumin) is characteristic of nephrotic syndrome.  The resultant decrease in plasma oncotic pressure promotes fluid movement into the interstitium; this leads to decreased EABV, resulting in secondary sodium retention (via RAAS activation), which contributes to edema.  Nephrotic syndrome would cause more significant proteinuria and is not typically associated with hematuria.

(Choice B)  Reduced albumin synthesis is characteristic of cirrhosis.  As in nephrotic syndrome, hypoalbuminemia decreases plasma oncotic pressure, which, combined with secondary sodium retention, contributes to edema in cirrhosis.  Cirrhosis would not explain lung crackles, hypertension, periorbital edema, and active urinary sediment (hematuria).

(Choice C)  Renal sodium retention due to decreased cardiac output is part of the vicious cycle of decompensated left-sided heart failure.  The sodium retention is secondary to decreased EABV, which causes RAAS activation.  Heart failure does not typically cause erythrocyte casts or severe hypertension.

(Choice E)  Venous congestion due to right ventricular (RV) failure causes edema by directly increasing capillary hydrostatic pressure.  Although RV failure causes JVD and anasarca, this patient's pulmonary edema is not consistent with isolated RV failure (ie, preserved left ventricular function).

Educational objective:
Generalized edema results from renal sodium retention and/or altered capillary hemodynamics.  Glomerulonephritis causes edema via primary glomerular injury, which increases sodium retention and expands plasma volume.  Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure then causes fluid movement into the interstitial space.

questionList.title: Glomerular disorders

answerChoiceList.choice: Low plasma oncotic pressure due to increased urinary protein excretion
Low plasma oncotic pressure due to reduced albumin synthesis
Renal sodium retention due to decreased cardiac output
Renal sodium retention due to primary glomerular injury
Venous congestion due to right ventricular failure

questionList.questionText: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin.  She also has hematuria but no dysuria or urinary frequency.  She has no other medical conditions and takes no medications.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 68/min.  The patient has no costovertebral angle tenderness.  Abdominal imaging shows a 6-mm calculus in the distal right ureter.  The patient's symptoms improve with intravenous hydration and analgesics.  Which of the following pharmacotherapy is recommended to facilitate stone passage?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has a 6-mm stone in the right distal ureter.  The resulting obstruction of urine flow increases intraureteral pressure and induces ureteral smooth muscle spasms that cause the characteristic pain of renal colic (eg, flank pain radiating to the groin).

The likelihood of a stone passing spontaneously is dependent on both stone size and location within the ureter.

  • Small stones (≤5 mm) that are distally located have a high probability of passing with expectant management alone (eg, fluids, pain control).

  • Stones that are large (>10 mm), regardless of their location, almost always require (outpatient) urologic intervention (eg, lithotripsy, stent placement) for resolution.

  • For stones that are moderately sized (>5 mm and ≤10 mm), medical expulsive therapy with an alpha-1 antagonist (eg, tamsulosin) should be considered.

Alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, which are located along the length of the ureter, mediate smooth muscle contraction.  Blocking these receptors can increase ureteral smooth muscle relaxation, decreasing spasms (thus reducing analgesic requirements) and facilitating stone passage.  The beneficial effects have been observed mainly in the treatment of distal ureteral stones; however, alpha-1 antagonists are a reasonable option for proximal stones as well given the relatively low risk of adverse effects.

(Choices A and C)  Activation of cholinergic receptors within the bladder smooth muscle stimulates contraction and facilitates voiding.  Bethanechol, a cholinergic agonist, promotes bladder emptying in patients with urinary retention from bladder hypotonia.  Conversely, oxybutynin, which has anticholinergic effects, promotes bladder muscle relaxation.  Oxybutynin is often prescribed for overactive bladder (detrusor instability).

(Choice B)  Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.  It is used in the management of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) to decrease prostatic volume.  Reducing prostate size usually takes months to years; finasteride is not used for acute symptom control even in BPH.

(Choice D)  Phenazopyridine is a urinary tract analgesic that provides symptom relief of dysuria (eg, due to urinary tract infection or instrumentation).  It has no effect on kidney stone passage.

Educational objective:
The likelihood of spontaneous ureteral stone passage decreases with increased stone size and proximal location.  Alpha-1 antagonists (eg, tamsulosin) may aid in stone expulsion by relaxing ureteral smooth muscle.  Their beneficial effects are seen most often in treatment of distal ureteral stones sized >5 mm and ≤10 mm.

questionList.questionText: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain.  He describes the pain as "sharp" and "unbearable."  It is located in the lower left abdomen and radiates to the groin.  He has vomited twice since it began.  The patient has no burning with urination.  He is afebrile.  He has difficulty lying still on the examination table due to the discomfort.  Mucous membranes appear slightly dry.  Lungs are clear to auscultation.  Heart sounds are normal and there are no murmurs or gallops.  The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation.  Inspection and palpation show normal genitalia.  Extremities have no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema.  Which of the following is the most appropriate test to diagnose this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient, with severe left lower abdominal pain radiating to the groin, vomiting, and unremarkable findings on abdominal examination, has typical features of obstructive ureterolithiasis.  Acute obstruction of the ureter at the ureterovesical junction produces severe flank pain that radiates to the perineum, penis, scrotum, or inner thigh.  Patients with ureteral stones are often writhing in pain and unable to sit still in the examination room.  Obstruction of hollow viscera often produces severe pain that is colicky in nature and poorly localized.  Other causes of visceral pain include obstruction of the small intestine, colon, common bile duct, gall bladder, or urinary bladder, each of which produces a characteristic pattern of referred pain.

The preferred modalities for diagnosing a ureteral stone are ultrasonography or noncontrast spiral CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.  Ultrasonography provides good imaging of the kidney and the proximal ureter and has lower radiation exposure.  It is preferred in patients with a low likelihood of alternate diagnosis and in pregnant patients.  However, it can also miss small stones, and its quality is dependent on the technician's expertise.

(Choice A)  Abdominal and pelvic x-ray (kidney-ureter-bladder study) will identify radiopaque, calcium-containing stones.  Other types of urinary stones, accounting for at least 15% of cases, are not visible on plain x-ray.  This method can also miss small stones at the ureterovesical junction.  X-ray gives no information about obstruction of the ureter or kidney.  However, it may be useful in serial follow-up of stones in the kidney or renal pelvis.

(Choice C)  Amylase and lipase help in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.  In acute pancreatitis, pain typically radiates to the back (upper lumbar region).

(Choice D)  Colonoscopy is usually not performed in patients with acute abdominal pain due to the risk of perforation.  If colonic obstruction is suspected and there is no evidence of perforation, a contrast enema study (barium or water-soluble contrast) can be diagnostic.

(Choice E)  Contrast is not required to visualize ureteral stones.  A noncontrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis can be obtained quickly, is very sensitive and specific, can visualize small or non-calcium stones, and may identify other potential causes of abdominal pain.

(Choice F)  Exploratory laparotomy is indicated when there is evidence of peritonitis, as from a perforated viscus (free air under the diaphragm), ruptured aortic aneurysm, or abdominal trauma.  Individuals with peritonitis typically lie still and avoid any movement that irritates the inflamed peritoneum.  There are no physical signs of peritonitis, such as guarding, rigidity, or rebound tenderness, in this patient.

(Choice G)  An intravenous pyelogram (IVP) uses IV contrast and plain x-ray to visualize the urinary system.  IVP was previously the test of choice for diagnosing urinary stones.  However, due to the risk of contrast administration (eg, allergy, acute kidney injury), noncontrast CT is now preferred.

(Choice H)  Radioisotope (HIDA) scan is indicated in patients with acute cholecystitis when ultrasonography cannot definitively demonstrate obstruction at the neck of the gall bladder.  In acute cholecystitis, pain is located predominantly in the upper abdomen and radiates to the tip of the right scapula or right shoulder.

(Choice I)  Urinalysis in patients with urinary stones will show microscopic or gross hematuria in over 90% of cases.  However, the presence of hematuria is nonspecific.  It is important to exclude coexistent urinary tract infection in patients with urinary calculi as this would significantly change management.  This patient has no history of fever or dysuria to suggest an infection.

Educational objective:
Ureteral calculi may cause flank or abdominal pain radiating to the perineum, often with nausea and vomiting.  Ultrasonography or a noncontrast spiral CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis are the imaging modalities of choice to confirm the diagnosis.  Ultrasonography is preferred in pregnant patients to reduce radiation exposure.

questionList.questionText:
A 57-year-old man arrives at the hospital with nausea, dark urine, and decreased urine output for 2 days.  For the past week, the patient has had generalized fatigue, muscle pain, and weakness.  He reports no recent fever, chills, sore throat, skin infection, or abdominal pain.  Medical history is significant for coronary artery disease with stenting to the right coronary artery, hypertension, gout, and obstructive sleep apnea.  Current medications include aspirin, ticagrelor, simvastatin, metoprolol, lisinopril, and colchicine.  The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 18/min.  There is no orthostasis.  Skin turgor is normal.  Oropharynx is clear.  Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities.  The abdomen is soft, nontender, and without bruit; there are no masses felt.  There is no peripheral edema.  The right great toe is slightly inflamed.  Laboratory studies reveal the following:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin13.8 g/dL
    Platelets260,000/mm3
    Leukocytes11,000/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium136 mEq/L
    Potassium5.6 mEq/L
    Chloride94 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate18 mEq/L
    Blood urea nitrogen50 mg/dL
    Creatinine4.2 mg/dL
    Glucose100 mg/dL
Urinalysis
    Proteinnone
    Blood3+
    White blood cells1-2/hpf
    Red blood cells1-2/hpf

Baseline laboratory studies conducted a month ago were normal.  Which of the following is most helpful to establish a diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Drug-induced rhabdomyolysis

Major mechanism

Examples

Direct myotoxicity

  • Statins, fibrates
  • Colchicine
  • Ethanol
  • Cocaine

Vasoconstrictive ischemia

  • Cocaine
  • Amphetamines

Prolonged immobilization
(compression ischemia)

  • Ethanol
  • Opioids
  • Benzodiazepines

This patient's presentation—muscle weakness, dark urine, decreased urine output, elevated creatinine, and blood on urinalysis without a significant number of red blood cells (RBCs) on urine microscopy—is consistent with rhabdomyolysis.  Rhabdomyolysis is commonly due to trauma (eg, crush injury, immobilization) or extreme exertion (eg, exercise in the heat), not seen in this patient.  However, both statins (eg, simvastatin) and colchicine are direct myotoxins and may trigger rhabdomyolysis, especially when used in combination.

Statins can cause many adverse effects on skeletal muscle (eg, asymptomatic inflammation, myopathy, rhabdomyolysis), possibly by impairing regulatory proteins (eg, coenzyme Q).  Colchicine inhibits microtubule function, leading to myocyte waste product accumulation.  Synergistic toxicity can lead to widespread skeletal muscle necrosis.  Myoglobin (containing heme) is released into the bloodstream and delivers heme pigments to the kidneys, where they create dark urine (pigmenturia) and can cause tubular toxicity and oliguric acute kidney injury (AKI).  The heme pigments are detected as blood on urinalysis; however, because true hematuria is absent, no RBCs are present on urine microscopy (ie, discordant blood findings on urine testing).

Potassium and phosphate release into the bloodstream can lead to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.  Creatine phosphokinase is a marker of skeletal muscle damage, and serum elevation >1,000 U/L confirms the diagnosis in the appropriate clinical setting.

(Choice A)  24-hour urine protein measurement is used to evaluate for nephrotic syndrome.  However, nephrotic syndrome typically causes foamy (rather than dark) urine, rarely causes profound AKI, and is extremely unlikely given the absence of proteinuria.

(Choice B)  Renal ultrasonography can detect hydronephrosis, which suggests urinary tract obstruction as a cause of AKI.  However, severe hydronephrosis is less likely in the absence of palpable abdominal masses and would not explain blood on urinalysis in the absence of RBCs.

(Choice C)  Renal vascular imaging (Doppler ultrasonography) can evaluate for renal artery stenosis (RAS) which, if bilateral, can cause severe AKI in patients on an ACE inhibitor (eg, lisinopril).  However, marked hypertension is expected, and RAS would not account for discordant blood findings on urine testing.

(Choice D)  Low serum complement (C3 and C4) levels help diagnose certain types of glomerulonephritis (eg, lupus nephritis, poststreptococcal), but true hematuria is expected with blood on urinalysis and RBCs on urine microscopy.

Educational objective:
Some drugs (eg, statins, colchicine) are directly myotoxic and may cause rhabdomyolysis, especially when used in combination.  Rhabdomyolysis is suggested by dark urine, blood on urinalysis in the absence of red blood cells on urine microscopy, and acute kidney injury.

questionList.questionText: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy, headache, and nausea since this morning.  In addition, the patient has had decreased urine output over the past 48 hours.  He reports no abdominal or joint pain, dysuria, or shortness of breath.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions; 2 weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 170/102 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 20/min.  The oropharynx is clear.  The neck is supple, and there is no lymphadenopathy.  Periorbital, scrotal, and pedal edema are present.  There is no rash.  Complete blood count is normal.  Serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL.  Urinalysis reveals moderate blood and 2+ protein.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

Pathophysiology

  • Several weeks after GAS infection (eg, pharyngitis, impetigo)
  • GBM immune complex deposition
  • Complement component C3 & CH50 accumulation

Clinical
features

  • Can be asymptomatic
  • If symptomatic:
    • Gross hematuria (tea- or cola-colored urine)
    • Edema (periorbital, generalized)
    • Hypertension

Laboratory
findings

  • Urinalysis: + protein, + blood, ± RBC casts
  • Serum:
    • ↑ Creatinine
    • ↓ C3 & CH50
    • Possible ↓ C4
    • Positive streptozyme test*

Management

  • Supportive care
  • Volume overload: loop diuretics
  • Hypertension: ± additional antihypertensives
  • Refractory cases: hemodialysis

Prognosis

  • Complete recovery in a few weeks in children
  • Adults more likely to develop chronic kidney disease

*Streptozyme tests: antistreptolysin O, anti-DNAse B, antihyaluronidase, anti–nicotinamide
adenine dinucleotidase, antistreptokinase.

GAS = group A Streptococcus; GBM = glomerular basement membrane; RBC = red blood cell.

This patient with hypertension, edema, and hematuria several weeks after group A Streptococcus infection (eg, pharyngitis) likely has acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN).  APSGN, a nephritic syndrome, results from immune-complex deposition between the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and the mesangium, as well as from complement (C3) activation and leukocytic inflammation that damages glomeruli.

Most cases are self-limited, with complete resolution and return to normal kidney function within weeks.  However, during the acute course, a spectrum of disease from asymptomatic to acute kidney injury and fulminant nephritic syndrome can occur, depending on the amount of immune complex deposition and GBM thickening.

Patients with nephritic syndrome, such as this one, have decreased glomerular filtration (eg, ↑ serum creatinine) and impaired sodium excretion (eg, hypertension).  Concurrent damage to the subepithelial podocytes results in increased urinary loss of protein and red blood cells (eg, hematuria, proteinuria), causing decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and third spacing.  The culmination of these effects leads to volume overload, with possible hypertension and edema requiring treatment with loop diuretics (eg, furosemide).  Adjunctive treatment with additional antihypertensives may be indicated (eg, hypertensive encephalopathy, hypertension refractory to diuresis), with possible dialysis in medically refractory cases.

(Choice A)  Protein restriction is used in chronic kidney disease because high protein intake may increase intraglomerular pressure and cause hyperfiltration, thereby aggravating the disease.  However, in APSGN, decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and protein spilling lead to volume overload and edema, which protein restriction does not help.

(Choice C)  When additional antihypertensive therapy is required (eg, hypertensive encephalopathy, no response to diuresis), calcium channel blockers (eg, nifedipine) are the drugs of choice.  ACE inhibitors (eg, lisinopril) are used with caution in acute kidney injury because of the risk of exacerbating hyperkalemia.

(Choice D)  In prerenal oliguria, a normal saline infusion may be indicated.  However, the oliguria in APSGN is secondary to decreased GFR due to intrarenal pathology; normal saline infusion would worsen this patient's volume overload, edema, and hypertension.

(Choice E)  Some antibody-mediated nephritic syndromes (eg, Goodpasture) are responsive to plasmapheresis; this young patient with recent pharyngitis and acute-onset symptoms most likely has APSGN.  Plasmapheresis is costly and not indicated because APSGN is self-limited.  In addition, clearing antibody-antigen complexes from blood does not clear them significantly faster from mesangium.

Educational objective:
Acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, a complication of group A Streptococcus infection (eg, pharyngitis), typically presents with hematuria, edema, and hypertension.  Management is mainly supportive.  Complications of volume overload (eg, hypertension, edema) require treatment with loop diuretics.

questionList.title: Acute kidney injury

questionList.questionText: A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to increasing left flank pain, nausea, and hematuria for 5 days.  The pain is dull, constant, and nonradiating.  Yesterday, the patient also noticed swelling of the left testis.  He was diagnosed with idiopathic membranous nephropathy 6 months ago. The diagnosis was confirmed by kidney biopsy and is medically managed.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min.  Examination reveals left flank tenderness.  Dilated and tortuous veins are noted in the left scrotum.  Bilateral 1+ pitting edema is also present.  Which of the following most likely underlies this patient's acute presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with membranous nephropathy, a common cause of nephrotic syndrome, shows evidence of an acute left renal vein thrombosis (RVT).  Occlusion of the left renal vein markedly increases glomerular pressure and causes hematuria and left-sided flank pain.  Because the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein, obstruction also causes left gonadal vein dilatation.  Risk factors for RVT include nephrotic syndrome (especially membranous nephropathy), renal malignancy, and trauma.

Nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia (<3 g/dL), peripheral edema, and hypercholesterolemia, is also associated with hypercoagulability.  As a consequence, patients who have nephrotic syndrome are at increased risk for deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and RVT.  Patients with hypoalbuminemia can become hypercoagulable as they also lose protein C, protein S, plasminogen, and antithrombin III in their urine.  In addition, nephrotic syndrome is associated with increased platelet activation and circulating levels of fibrinogen among other hemostatic abnormalities.  Patients with RVT and acute kidney injury should undergo urgent clot removal (eg, thrombolysis).  Otherwise, anticoagulation alone is appropriate.

(Choice A)  Although patients with nephrotic syndrome and hypoalbuminemia are at increased risk for thrombosis, it is the loss of anticoagulant proteins in their urine that is more important to the pathogenesis.  Reduced serum albumin (with subsequently diminished oncotic pressure) is a marker for the loss of these other proteins rather than the pathophysiologic mechanism.

(Choice C)  Patients prone to nephrolithiasis are often found to have elevated urinary calcium excretion.  Nephrolithiasis causes acute flank pain and macroscopic hematuria; however, this patient's edema and left testicular swelling would not be expected.

(Choice D)  Renal cell carcinomas (RCC) can cause gross hematuria, flank pain, and subacute to chronic development of testicular swelling due to infiltration of the collecting system and obstruction of the renal vein.  However, these symptoms do not commonly present acutely, and most patients with symptomatic RCC have preceding anemia, cachexia, or other evidence of malignancy.

(Choice E)  Urinary tract infections typically cause dysuria and urinary hesitancy and frequency, although microscopic or macroscopic hematuria and flank pain may be seen, depending on the severity of infection.  The absence of fevers and the presence of dilated scrotal veins make this diagnosis less likely.

Educational objective:
Renal vein thrombosis, which can present with hematuria, flank pain, and scrotal edema (in men), is an important complication of nephrotic syndrome.  Nephrotic syndrome, and membranous nephropathy in particular, is associated with the urinary loss of several endogenous anticoagulant proteins, resulting in hypercoagulability.

questionList.questionText:
A 17-year-old boy is evaluated in the office due to progressive facial puffiness, fatigue, and decreased appetite for the past month.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Physical examination shows periorbital and pretibial edema.  Serum laboratory results are as follows:

Creatinine0.9 mg/dL
Albumin2.2 mg/dL

Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria, no red blood cells, and no casts.  A renal biopsy is performed.  Immunofluorescence microscopy shows a diffuse, granular pattern of IgG and C3 along the capillary loops, and electron microscopy shows electron-dense immune deposits along the glomerular basement membrane, findings consistent with membranous nephropathy.  Which of the following additional studies should be performed in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Membranous nephropathy

Epidemiology

  • Adults: common, usually idiopathic/primary disease
  • Children: rare, usually secondary disease

Pathogenesis

  • Gradual subepithelial immune complex deposition & podocyte damage

Associated conditions

  • Malignancy
  • Infection (eg, hepatitis B)
  • Autoimmune (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, thyroiditis)
  • Drugs (eg, NSAIDs, penicillamine)

Presentation

  • Subacute nephrotic syndrome
    • Edema
    • Proteinuria
    • Hyperlipidemia & hypoalbuminemia
  • BP & GFR usually normal

Prognosis

  • Partial/full remission common (spontaneous or treatment induced)
  • End-stage kidney disease rare

BP = blood pressure; GFR = glomerular filtration rate; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

This patient with edema and marked proteinuria has nephrotic syndrome from membranous nephropathy (MN), which is due to the accumulation of subepithelial immune deposits.  Although MN is often idiopathic or primary (ie, autoantibodies against endogenous glomerular antigens) in adults, the diagnosis should prompt an evaluation for secondary causes, particularly in children who rarely develop primary disease (Choice E).  The following conditions are associated with MN:

  • Malignancy (usually solid tumors in adults)
  • Infection (eg, hepatitis B virus [HBV], hepatitis C virus, syphilis)
  • Autoimmune disease (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, thyroiditis)
  • Drugs (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs)

Because MN pathogenesis involves gradual podocyte damage from accumulating immune deposits, onset is typically subacute, unlike other common nephrotic syndromes that present acutely (eg, minimal change disease).

In patients with HBV, MN is caused by immune complexes formed from hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) and anti-HBeAg.  Therefore, chronic HBV infection is a significant risk factor for MN, particularly in children.  Evaluating all patients with MN with HBV serologies is recommended, although universal HBV vaccination had reduced the rates of HBV-associated MN.

(Choice A)  Antistreptolysin O titers are useful in the diagnosis of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).  PSGN is commonly associated with hematuria, not seen in this patient.  Although nephrotic-range proteinuria can occur, it is less common, and most patients have hypertension and elevated creatinine.  Streptococcal infection is not associated with MN.

(Choice B)  An audiology evaluation is indicated for patients diagnosed with Alport syndrome, which presents with hematuria due to defective type IV collagen.  Patients often have a family history, and the disease classically presents following a respiratory tract infection.  MN is not associated with increased risk of hearing loss.

(Choice C)  Amyloidosis can present with nephrotic syndrome due to glomerular amyloid deposition.  Echocardiography is indicated in these patients due to the risk of restrictive cardiomyopathy, which is not associated with MN.

Educational objective:
Membranous nephropathy causes gradual-onset nephrotic syndrome (ie, edema, proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia) and most commonly occurs in adults as primary disease.  However, the diagnosis in any patient should prompt evaluation for a secondary cause, such as hepatitis B infection, autoimmune disease (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus), and malignancy.

questionList.questionText:
A 24-year-old man comes to the urgent care clinic due to concern for bloody urine.  He has had bilateral flank discomfort since yesterday associated with a single episode of dark red urine.  He says that his urine is now a normal yellow color.  The patient also has had a sore throat for the past 4 days, for which he took 3 acetaminophen tablets.  He has had no fever, abdominal pain, or burning during urination.  He has a 5-pack-year history.  The patient has no medical conditions and does not take medications regularly.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Urinalysis results are as follows:

Coloryellow
Glucosenegative
Protein2+
Ketonesnegative
Leukocyte esterasenegative
Nitritesnegative
White blood cells2-3/hpf
Red blood cells50-75/hpf

Which of the following is the most likely source of this patient's urinary findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Glomerular vs nonglomerular hematuria

Glomerular

Nonglomerular

RBC casts

May be seen1

Absent

Dysmorphic RBCs

Often present2

Rare, usually normal (ie, isomorphic)

Proteinuria3

Often ≥1+ (>500 mg/day)

Usually negative or trace (<500 mg/day)

Color

Dark red or brown (cola, tea)

Bright red or pink

Clots

Absent

Possible1

  1. Virtually pathognomonic when present.
  2. Acanthocytes highly specific; phase-contrast microscopy often needed for visualization.
  3. Urine dipstick sensitive for albuminuria (ie, glomerular proteinuria).

RBC = red blood cell.

Hematuria results from glomerular or nonglomerular sources.  Nonglomerular hematuria (more common) can be gross or microscopic and is characterized by a bright red or pink color, normal-appearing red blood cells (RBCs), and limited proteinuria (<500 mg/day).  Common causes include infection, nephrolithiasis, cancer (eg, renal cell), and urogenital trauma.  Associated symptoms (eg, dysuria, unilateral flank pain) often provide diagnostic clues.

In contrast, glomerular hematuria is typically microscopic, although gross blood is sometimes present.  It usually results from immune-mediated glomerular injury (ie, glomerulonephritis), which produces dysmorphic RBCs (RBC squeezing through damaged glomerular basement membranes) and/or RBC casts (virtually diagnostic if present).  However, the absence of dysmorphic RBCs or RBC casts does not exclude glomerular bleeding: both findings can be missed for various reasons (eg, prolonged centrifugation).  Therefore, other signs of potential glomerular injury should be noted, including:

  • Dark red or brown color:  Hemoglobin oxidizes to methemoglobin during prolonged nephron transport.

  • Albuminuria (ie, glomerular proteinuria):  Urine dipstick is specific; higher quantitative levels (>500 mg/day) are suggestive.

This patient's albuminuria (2+ dipstick), dark red urine (albeit transient), and bilateral flank pain (vs unilateral suggesting a nonglomerular cause) are consistent with glomerular hematuria.  Concurrent pharyngitis (ie, synpharyngitic) suggests the glomerulonephritis is most likely from IgA nephropathy.

(Choices B and F)  Prostate and bladder disorders (eg, malignancy/hyperplasia, infection) cause nonglomerular hematuria.  Moreover, this young patient is unlikely to have urogenital malignancy or benign prostatic hyperplasia, and there is no evidence of infection by symptoms (eg, dysuria) or urinalysis (eg, negative leukocyte esterase, no pyuria [defined as >10 white cells/hpf]).

(Choices C and D)  Acute interstitial nephritis most commonly follows drug exposure (eg, antibiotic) and can cause nonglomerular hematuria.  However, urinalysis typically shows white blood cells/casts (lacking in this patient), and acetaminophen is an unlikely cause.  Chronic interstitial nephritis (CIN) can result from acetaminophen use; however, long-term (vs light-intermittent) intake is characteristic.  Interstitial inflammation from CIN can also cause renal papillary necrosis (RPN) from papillary artery ischemia.  However, this patient lacks findings of CIN (eg, pyuria) and has no evidence of other RPN-predisposing disorders (eg, ischemia-prone disorders such as sickle cell).

(Choice E)  Acute tubular necrosis results from hypotensive or nephrotoxic injury.  Urinalysis classically shows muddy brown casts without significant hematuria or proteinuria.  Tumors originating from renal tubules (eg, renal cell) cause nonglomerular hematuria without significant proteinuria.

Educational objective:
Glomerular hematuria is characterized by dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs) and/or RBC casts on urinalysis.  When these findings are absent, albuminuria and/or dark urine suggests a glomerular source.

questionList.title: Glomerular disorders

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up after a recent visit to the emergency department due to vomiting and severe right flank pain 6 weeks ago.  Imaging revealed a 4-mm stone in the right midureter, which she passed at home a week later.  The patient has been to the emergency department twice in the past 5 years due to similar episodes of renal colic.  Both times, the stones passed spontaneously, and she did not seek further medical care.  The patient has been following dietary instructions and drinking plenty of fluids.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  A 24-hour urine collection shows urinary calcium excretion of 350 mg (normal: <250 in women).  Laboratory results show a serum calcium concentration of 8.9 mg/dL; serum parathyroid hormone is normal.  Further investigations fail to demonstrate a cause of the hypercalciuria.  Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Prevention of calcium stone (calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate) recurrence

Intervention

Mechanism

Dietary
interventions

All calcium stones:

↑ Fluid (produce >2 L/day urine)

↑ Urine flow, ↓ solute concentration

↓ Sodium (<2,300 mg/day)

↑ Renal calcium reabsorption

↑ Citrate (fruits & vegetables)

Binds urinary calcium to inhibit stone formation

↑ Potassium

↑ Urinary citrate excretion

↓ Animal protein

↓ Urinary calcium excretion

Calcium oxalate stones:

Adequate calcium intake (1,200 mg/day)

↓ Oxalate absorption in GI tract

↓ Oxalate (spinach)

↓ Urinary oxalate excretion

Pharmacologic
interventions

Thiazide diuretics

↑ Renal calcium reabsorption

Potassium citrate

↑ Urinary citrate concentration

GI = gastrointestinal.

This patient has recurrent nephrolithiasis with elevated urinary calcium (ie, hypercalciuria) and an otherwise normal medical evaluation.  She most likely has idiopathic hypercalciuria, which is characterized by hypercalciuria in the presence of normal serum calcium levels and the absence of an identifiable disease process (eg, hyperparathyroidism) that alters calcium metabolism and/or absorption.

Hypercalciuria greatly increases the risk for recurrent calcium (eg, calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate) stone formation and can be treated with increased fluid intake (eg, ≥2 L/day) and dietary measures alone in most patients.  Dietary measures include low sodium (↑ renal calcium reabsorption), low animal protein (↓ urinary calcium excretion), high citrate (fruits/vegetables) consumption (binds urinary calcium), and adequate dietary calcium (↓ oxalate absorption).  If these measures fail (eg, recurrent stones, increased size of old stones, persistent hypercalciuria) after a 3- to 6-month trial, as seen in this patient, pharmacotherapy with a thiazide diuretic is recommended.

Thiazide diuretics (eg, chlorthalidone) decrease urinary calcium excretion by up to 50% and significantly reduce the formation of new calcium stones.  In addition to increasing calcium reabsorption at the level of the distal tubule, thiazides produce relative hypovolemia that results in a compensatory increase in sodium reabsorption, which is tightly coupled to calcium reabsorption, at the level of the proximal tubule and loop of Henle.  A low-sodium diet is crucial for these medications to work effectively.

(Choice A)  Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (eg, acetazolamide) block bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, creating an alkaline urine that increases the risk for precipitation of calcium phosphate stones.

(Choice C)  Loop diuretics (eg, furosemide) promote calcium wasting by the kidney.  The resulting increase in urinary calcium excretion increases the risk for calcium stone formation.

(Choices D and E)  Sodium citrate increases urinary citrate levels; and sodium bicarbonate alkalinizes the serum, which promotes renal citrate excretion.  Urinary citrate can bind calcium (creating a soluble complex) and inhibit calcium stone formation.  However, the increased sodium load with sodium citrate and sodium bicarbonate counteracts this positive effect because it leads to increased urinary calcium excretion due to the tight coupling of sodium and calcium reabsorption in the proximal tubule and loop of Henle.  Potassium citrate or potassium bicarbonate can be used instead.

Educational objective:
Hypercalciuria increases the risk for calcium stone recurrence.  If increased fluid intake and dietary measures are ineffective at preventing stones, thiazide diuretics should be added.  Thiazide diuretics increase renal calcium reabsorption, decrease urinary calcium concentration, and significantly reduce the formation of new calcium stones.

Effectiveness of treatment modalities on kidney stone recurrence.

questionList.questionText:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office due to dark brown urine and fatigue for a week.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 140/94 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
    Blood urea nitrogen24 mg/dL
    Creatinine1.7 mg/dL
Urinalysis
    Specific gravity1.016
    Protein+2
    Bloodmoderate
    Leukocyte esterasenegative
    Nitritesnegative
    White blood cells1-2/hpf
    Red blood cells20-30/hpf

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Hematuria can be due to a nonglomerular or glomerular source.  The most common cause of gross hematuria in children is nonglomerular (eg, urinary tract infection, perineal/meatal irritation, trauma).  However, glomerular disease should be suspected with any of the following:

  • Red blood cell casts (pathognomonic)
  • Proteinuria
  • Hypertension
  • Edema
  • Brown, cola-colored urine (in contrast to red/pink urine with lower urinary tract bleeding)

Therefore, this patient with dark brown urine, in addition to 2+ proteinuria, hypertension, and elevated creatinine, likely has a glomerular source of bleeding.

Initial evaluation of glomerulonephritis includes serum complement (C3, C4) levels, as well as a complete blood count and albumin level.  Low C3 is suggestive of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), the most common glomerulonephritis in children, or lupus nephritis.  Antistreptolysin O (seen in PSGN) and antinuclear antibody (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) testing can help differentiate these conditions.  If laboratory evaluation is unrevealing and symptoms persist, renal biopsy may be indicated for diagnosis (eg, IgA nephropathy, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis).

(Choices A, B, and C)  Bladder imaging may be indicated for painless hematuria to evaluate for a tumor; because of radiation exposure, ultrasound, not CT scan, is typically preferred as the initial imaging study in children.  Visualization/tissue sampling via cystoscopy is diagnostic.  However, bladder tumors are extremely rare in children, cause pink/red (not brown) urine, and are not typically associated with proteinuria, hypertension, or elevated creatinine.

(Choice D)  Hemoglobin electrophoresis is diagnostic of sickle cell trait, which can cause papillary necrosis from sickling within capillaries of the renal medulla.  The classic presentation is isolated, painless, gross hematuria; hypertension, proteinuria, and elevated creatinine are atypical.  Moreover, in children, PSGN is far more common than renal papillary necrosis.

(Choices E and G)  Management of patients with hematuria and other symptoms of a urinary tract infection (eg, dysuria, urgency, frequency) includes empiric antibiotics, urine culture, and repeat urinalysis in 2 weeks to confirm resolution of hematuria.  Urine is typically pink or red, not brown, and urinalysis classically shows pyuria (white blood cells ≥5/hpf), leukocyte esterase, and/or nitrites, none of which is seen here.  In addition, asymptomatic microscopic hematuria may also be followed by serial urinalyses, but this patient has symptomatic gross hematuria that warrants further evaluation.

Educational objective:
Glomerular sources of gross hematuria should be considered in a patient with brown urine, red blood cell casts, proteinuria, hypertension, and/or edema.  Initial evaluation includes serum complement (C3, C4) levels.

questionList.questionText:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office due to bright red blood in the urine for the past day.  He has had no dysuria, urgency, frequency, or pain.  There is no history of trauma.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions or recent infections and takes no medications.  Temperature is 98.6 F (37 C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, and respirations are 20/min.  Examination shows normal cardiopulmonary, abdominal, and genital examinations.  There is no flank or suprapubic tenderness.  There is no edema.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
Blood urea nitrogen14 mg/dL
Creatinine0.8 mg/dL
Urinalysis
Specific gravity1.019
Proteinnone
Blood3+
Leukocyte esterasenegative
Nitritesnegative
Bacterianone
White blood cells2-4/hpf
Red blood cells100+/hpf
Castsnone

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has acute-onset asymptomatic gross hematuria with no history of trauma, signs/symptoms of infection (eg, dysuria, pyuria, leukocyte esterase), or evidence of glomerular disease (eg, casts, proteinuria, hypertension).  Common conditions associated with isolated gross hematuria in children include meatal irritation, which is usually painful and may be visible on external examination, and nephrolithiasis.

Classic symptoms of nephrolithiasis (eg, flank/abdominal pain) commonly occur in older children and adults as the stone passes through the urinary tract and obstructs the ureter.  However, young children are more likely to have stones located in the kidney, which are painless and cause an atypical presentation of gross hematuria alone, as seen in this patient.  Apart from confirming hematuria (eg, urine dipstick positive for blood, red blood cells on microscopy), urinalysis may be otherwise unrevealing because characteristic crystals are not always present.  A major risk factor for nephrolithiasis is hypercalciuria, which may be suspected because of a previous history of microscopic hematuria and confirmed with an elevated spot urine calcium/creatinine ratio.

The preferred imaging study for evaluation of suspected nephrolithiasis in children is renal and bladder ultrasonography, which can detect some stones and ureteral obstruction while avoiding radiation exposure.  Ultrasonography is also the initial imaging study of choice for excluding less common, but serious causes of nonglomerular hematuria, such as a renal mass (eg, Wilms tumor), a condition usually associated with abdominal mass/swelling.  If ultrasonography is nondiagnostic, CT scan of the abdomen without contrast may be required because it is more sensitive for identifying small calculi (Choice B).

(Choices A and D)  Glomerular disease can present with gross hematuria, and evaluation may include 24-hour urine protein or diagnostic kidney biopsy.  Additional signs of glomerulonephritis include hypertension, edema, proteinuria, and red blood cell casts, which are not seen in this patient.  Moreover, brown urine is typical of glomerulonephritis, and bright red urine, as seen in this patient, usually indicates a nonglomerular source of bleeding.

(Choice C)  Cystoscopy is typically performed in adults to evaluate for bladder cancer, which is a very rare cause of painless gross hematuria in children.  In addition, evaluation with bladder ultrasonography would precede an invasive procedure.

Educational objective:
Young children may have an atypical presentation of nephrolithiasis with isolated gross hematuria in the absence of abdominal or flank pain.  Because of radiation exposure associated with CT scans, renal and bladder ultrasonography is the preferred imaging study for detecting stones in children.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to acute-onset left-sided flank pain, hematuria, and vomiting.  He has regular bowel movements.  Medical history is significant for Crohn disease complicated by multiple strictures that required surgical resection of the small intestine.  Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), blood pressure is 120/65 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 16/min.  BMI is 22 kg/m2.  The abdomen is soft and mildly tender over the left flank with no rebound or rigidity.  Bowel sounds are decreased.  A laparotomy scar is present.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has flank pain, hematuria, and vomiting suggestive of nephrolithiasis.  Given his history of Crohn disease and small bowel resection, he likely has fat malabsorption that has predisposed him to hyperoxaluria and calcium oxalate stones.

Under normal conditions, dietary calcium binds dietary oxalate in the intestine, forming insoluble calcium oxalate salts that are eliminated in the feces.  In malabsorption syndromes that develop with small bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease) or surgical small bowel diversion (eg, gastric bypass), excess fatty acids (which are normally reabsorbed in the ileum) remain in the intestinal lumen.  These fatty acids form complexes with calcium and decrease the amount of calcium available for binding oxalate.  As a result, enteric oxalate absorption is increased.  Oxalate is subsequently filtered into the urine, where an increased level (ie, hyperoxaluria) promotes the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

(Choice A)  Increased enteric absorption of calcium, induced by calcitriol (the active form of vitamin D), results in hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, and an increased risk of calcium stones.  Conditions that increase calcitriol levels include hyperparathyroidism (via increased renal hydroxylation of calcidiol) and granulomatous diseases like sarcoidosis (via extrarenal production of calcitriol by macrophages).  There is nothing in this patient's clinical history to suggest either disorder; his history of Crohn disease makes hyperoxaluria the more likely cause of nephrolithiasis.

(Choice C)  Increased recycling of bile salts and fatty acids would reduce the amount available to bind dietary calcium.  This would result in more calcium available to bind dietary oxalate, which would limit enteric oxalate absorption, reduce the concentration of urinary oxalate, and decrease the risk for calcium oxalate stones.  Malabsorption syndromes (eg, Crohn disease, small bowel resection) decrease (not increase) recycling of bile salts and fatty acids.

(Choice D)  Increased urinary citrate excretion would be protective against nephrolithiasis.  Citrate inhibits the formation of calcium stones by binding with urinary calcium and creating a complex that is soluble in urine.

(Choice E)  Increased urinary uric acid excretion, seen in gout and myeloproliferative disorders, predisposes patients to uric acid stones.  This patient's risk of hyperoxaluria from Crohn disease makes calcium oxalate stones more likely.

Educational objective:
In malabsorption syndromes (eg, Crohn disease), excess luminal fatty acids sequester dietary calcium, which reduces calcium binding of oxalate and allows more oxalate to be enterically absorbed.  Oxalate is subsequently filtered into the urine, where an increased level (ie, hyperoxaluria) promotes calcium oxalate stone formation.

questionList.questionText:
A 35-year-old, previously healthy man is evaluated due to swelling of the face, abdomen, and legs over the past 4 weeks.  Facial edema is worse on awakening.  The patient has gained 7 kg (15.4 lb) over this period.  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 133/75 mm Hg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Physical examination shows periorbital edema, moderate ascites, and 2+ bilateral pitting lower extremity edema.  Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates no abnormalities.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum
Creatinine0.9 mg/dL
Total protein4.5 g/dL
Albumin2.3 g/dL
PT11 sec

This patient is at the greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
This young, previously healthy patient has developed sudden-onset generalized edema (eg, lower extremity and periorbital edema, ascites) with weight gain.  Hypoalbuminemia suggests that the cause is nephrotic syndrome, which involves increased permeability of the glomerular capillary, leading to urinary albumin loss.  Hypoalbuminemia leads to decreased plasma oncotic pressure, thereby causing fluid to shift from the intravascular space into the interstitial space (ie, third spacing).

To compensate, the decreased plasma oncotic pressure seems to stimulate increased hepatic synthesis of proteins, including albumin (though in insufficient amounts to compensate for the urinary loss).  In addition, there is increased hepatic synthesis of lipoproteins as well as decreased LDL clearance (due to increased synthesis of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 [PCSK9], which causes LDL receptor degradation).  These 2 factors, combined with decreased endothelial lipoprotein lipase activity, result in hyperlipidemia, thereby increasing the risk for accelerated atherosclerosis.

Nephrotic syndrome also leads to the following other complications:

  • Thrombotic events (eg, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, renal vein thrombosis) due to urinary loss of natural anticoagulants (antithrombin III, proteins C and S)

  • Bacterial infections, particularly from encapsulated organisms (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae) due to urinary loss of immunoglobulins (ie, humoral immunity)

Additional findings may include vitamin D deficiency (urinary loss of vitamin D–binding protein) and anemia (urinary loss of transferrin and erythropoietin).

(Choice B)  Although hypoalbuminemia in nephrotic syndrome decreases total serum calcium, the physiologically active ionized calcium remains normal.  Therefore, parathyroid hormone level is typically normal.

(Choice C)  Monoclonal gammopathy (eg, multiple myeloma) can cause nephrotic syndrome from amyloidosis.  However, nephrotic syndrome itself does not increase the risk for monoclonal gammopathy.  Excess immunoglobulin production is unlikely in this young patient with a normal gamma gap (ie, difference between total protein and albumin).

(Choice D)  Variceal hemorrhage is a potential complication of cirrhosis, which also commonly causes generalized edema.  However, cirrhosis is unlikely in this patient with a normal prothrombin time (indicating intact hepatic protein synthesis) and sudden-onset edema (cirrhosis develops slowly over years).

(Choice E)  Although urinary loss of transcobalamin (vitamin B12 carrier protein) and unbound vitamin B12 may be seen in nephrotic syndrome, clinically significant vitamin B12 deficiency is rare.  This is likely because urinary losses are compensated by large total body stores (ie, several years) of vitamin B12.

Educational objective:
Nephrotic syndrome results in albuminuria, which reduces plasma oncotic pressure and leads to edema.  To compensate, increased hepatic lipoprotein synthesis and impaired lipid catabolism occur, resulting in hyperlipidemia with accelerated atherosclerosis.

questionList.questionText:
A 50-year-old man comes to the office due to polyuria and polydipsia for the past month.  He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 15/min.  BMI is 30 kg/m2.  Physical examination is normal.  Serum chemistry panel is as follows:

Sodium140 mEq/L
Potassium4.1 mEq/L
Bicarbonate26 mEq/L
Blood glucose210 mg/dL
Blood urea nitrogen12 mg/dL
Creatinine0.9 mg/dL

What is the most sensitive test for screening for nephropathy in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has an elevated blood glucose (≥200 mg/dL) with symptoms of hyperglycemia (ie, polyuria, polydipsia), findings supporting a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Diabetic nephropathy (DN) is an important microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus and increases the risk for end-stage renal disease.  DN is detectable in patients starting 5 years after the diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus but is often already present at diagnosis in patients with type 2, who have often had asymptomatic hyperglycemia for several years.

DN is characterized by the following physiologic effects:

  • Altered glomerular filtration:  Initially, elevated intraglomerular pressures cause hyperfiltration (likely mediated by multiple mechanisms, including sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT) activity); serum creatinine may be normal or low despite significant glomerular injury and is an insensitive test for early DN.  As DN progresses, filtration falls, and serum creatinine rises.

  • Increased protein (eg, albumin) excretion:  Assessment of proteinuria involves measuring the urine albumin/creatinine ratio (UACR) (ie, ratio of urine albumin [in milligrams] to urine creatinine [in grams]).  UACR >30 mg/g suggests DN.

UACR is highly sensitive for DN at all stages and should be assessed regularly, beginning at the time of diagnosis of type 2 diabetes.  If DN is detected, the patient should be prescribed pharmacologic agents proved to reduce the progression of nephropathy, including a SGLT-2 inhibitor and an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin II receptor blocker.

(Choice A)  A creatinine clearance assay (ie, 24-hour urine creatinine excretion ÷ serum creatinine concentration) can provide a direct assessment of glomerular filtration.  However, because hyperfiltration can alter serum creatinine results, it is an insensitive marker for early DN.

(Choice B)  Dipstick urine protein testing is insensitive to moderate albuminuria, and results can vary depending on urine concentration.  UACR is a more sensitive assay.

(Choice C)  Oral glucose tolerance testing is often used to diagnose gestational diabetes mellitus but has no role in the detection of DN.

(Choice D)  Early DN is not associated with visible changes in ultrasonography; a change in kidney size is seen primarily in advanced renal failure.

Educational objective:
Diabetic nephropathy is characterized by altered glomerular filtration (initial hyperfiltration and, later, decreased filtration) and increased protein (eg, albumin) excretion.  The most sensitive test is the urine albumin/creatinine ratio, which should be assessed regularly beginning at the diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Diabetic kidney disease

answerChoiceList.choice: Dipstick testing of urine for protein

questionList.questionText:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office due to a weeklong history of generalized edema and fatigue.  Otherwise, he has been well, and his medical history is significant only for obesity.  The patient takes a daily multivitamin and no other medications.  BMI is at the 98th percentile for age.  Blood pressure is 92/55 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min.  Periorbital edema and 1+ pretibial edema are found on examination.  The scrotum is mildly swollen but nontender.  Abdominal examination is unremarkable.  Urinalysis results are as follows:

Specific gravity1.028
pH5
Protein4+
Bloodnegative
Castsnone
Crystalsnone

Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathogenesis for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Minimal change disease

Epidemiology

  • Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children

Pathogenesis

  • T-cell–mediated injury to podocytes → ↑ molecular permeability to albumin

Clinical features

  • Edema (eg, periorbital, scrotal, generalized)
  • Fatigue
  • ± Abdominal pain

Diagnosis

  • Urine: nephrotic-range proteinuria
  • Serum: hypoalbuminemia ± hyperlipidemia
  • Kidney biopsy*: diffuse effacement of foot processes on EM

Treatment

  • Corticosteroids

Prognosis

  • Most achieve remission, but relapse is common
  • Low risk of chronic kidney disease if episodes are steroid responsive

*Indicated only for atypical cases.

EM = electron microscopy.

This patient has generalized edema and isolated, marked proteinuria, findings consistent with nephrotic syndrome.  The most likely cause in a child is minimal change disease (MCD), which accounts for 80% of pediatric cases of nephrotic syndrome.

The pathogenesis of MCD begins with dysregulation of T-cell subpopulations.  Dysfunctional T cells release cytokines (eg, IL-13) that damage the capillary wall of the glomerulus, leading to epithelial podocyte injury and loss of charge selectivity across the glomerular basement membrane.  This allows for urinary loss of anions (eg, albumin), causing marked proteinuria.  The resulting hypoalbuminemia leads to decreased plasma oncotic pressure and acute-onset, gravity-dependent edema (eg, periorbital, scrotal, tibial).  Rapid fluid accumulation may result in generalized edema (ie, anasarca) with ascites and pleural effusions.  Children with MCD often have nonspecific symptoms (eg, fatigue, headache), as seen in this patient.

Diagnosis of MCD is clinical with kidney biopsy reserved for atypical cases.  If performed, light microscopy demonstrates normal kidney architecture, and immunofluorescence staining of the glomeruli is negative.  Diffuse effacement of foot processes of podocytes on electron microscopy confirms the diagnosis.

(Choice B)  Renal amyloidosis can cause nephrotic syndrome due to glomerular amyloid deposition.  This condition is exceedingly rare in children and typically associated with progressive, chronic disease.

(Choice C)  Alport syndrome (hereditary nephritis) is characterized by a glomerular collagen abnormality that causes hematuria, not severe proteinuria, in childhood.  Moreover, patients frequently have a positive family history, which is not seen in this child.

(Choice D)  Glomerulosclerosis is seen in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which also causes nephrotic syndrome in children.  However, in addition to being much less common than MCD in this age group, FSGS also commonly causes hematuria and hypertension, making this diagnosis less likely in this patient.

(Choice E)  Immune complex deposition occurs in several pediatric nephropathies (eg, acute poststreptococcal and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis) and can lead to edema from proteinuria.  However, these syndromes also present with hematuria, which is not seen in this patient.

Educational objective:
Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.  Pathogenesis involves cytokine-induced glomerular injury, which damages epithelial podocytes, leading to a massive urinary loss of protein, hypoalbuminemia, and edema.

questionList.title: Minimal change glomerulopathy

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Minimal change disease.

questionList.questionText:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to sudden-onset severe, colicky pain in the right flank.  The patient had a similar episode 3 years ago; it resolved a few days later after he passed "gravel" in his urine.  He has no other medical conditions and no history of urinary infections.  The patient usually eats precooked food from a local store and has a soda with each meal.  Vital signs are stable.  He is given intravenous fluids and pain medication.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin14.5 g/dL
Leukocytes13,000/mm3; no bands
Platelets300,000/mm3
Blood urea nitrogen16 mg/dL
Creatinine0.8 mg/dL

CT scan of the abdomen without contrast reveals renal calculi.  Urinalysis shows moderate levels of blood and calcium oxalate crystals.  Which of the following dietary changes is most likely to decrease this patient's risk for recurrence of similar symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Prevention of calcium stone (calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate) recurrence

Intervention

Mechanism

Dietary
interventions

All calcium stones:

↑ Fluid (produce >2 L/day urine)

↑ Urine flow, ↓ solute concentration

↓ Sodium (<2,300 mg/day)

↑ Renal calcium reabsorption

↑ Citrate (fruits & vegetables)

Binds urinary calcium to inhibit stone formation

↑ Potassium

↑ Urinary citrate excretion

↓ Animal protein

↓ Urinary calcium excretion

Calcium oxalate stones:

Adequate calcium intake (1,200 mg/day)

↓ Oxalate absorption in GI tract

↓ Oxalate (spinach)

↓ Urinary oxalate excretion

Pharmacologic
interventions

Thiazide diuretics

↑ Renal calcium reabsorption

Potassium citrate

↑ Urinary citrate concentration

GI = gastrointestinal.

This patient has recurrent nephrolithiasis due to calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of renal stone.  Prevention of recurrent stone formation involves decreasing the urinary concentration of stone-forming components (eg, increasing fluid intake, decreasing urinary excretion of calcium and oxalate) and increasing factors (eg, urinary citrate) that inhibit stone formation.  Multiple dietary interventions, including the following, may help prevent recurrent nephrolithiasis:

  • Limited sodium diet (eg, <2,300 mg/day):  Calcium reabsorption is tightly coupled to sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule and loop of Henle, which, together, are responsible for >90% of calcium handling in the nephron.  Decreased sodium intake leads to increased reabsorption of sodium and water, which increases passive calcium reabsorption.  The resulting decreased urine calcium concentration reduces the likelihood of stone formation.

  • Normal dietary calcium intake (eg, 1,200 mg/day):  Calcium ingested at meals (vs supplemented via a pill) binds oxalate in the intestinal lumen and prevents oxalate absorption.  This results in decreased urine oxalate excretion, diminishing the risk for calcium oxalate stone formation (Choice A).

  • Potassium-rich diet:  Potassium-rich foods (eg, fruits, vegetables) have been associated with increased urine citrate excretion.  Citrate binds calcium, creating a soluble complex that decreases the availability of calcium to form stones (Choice B).

(Choice D)  Higher intake of animal protein is associated with both higher urine calcium excretion and lower urine citrate levels, which may contribute to calcium stone formation.

(Choice E)  A high-oxalate diet can increase oxaluria and the risk for calcium oxalate stones.  Patients are advised to limit excessive intake of oxalate-rich foods (eg, spinach, potatoes).  Complete restriction is not recommended, however, because many oxalate-containing fruits and vegetables also provide essential potassium and citrate, which are protective against stone formation.

Educational objective:
Dietary modifications that decrease urine calcium and oxalate excretion and/or increase urine citrate levels may help prevent recurrent calcium oxalate stones.  These include limiting the intake of sodium, oxalate, and animal protein; increasing consumption of potassium-rich foods; and maintaining a normal intake of dietary calcium.
