questionList.questionText:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 10 weeks gestation comes to the office for an initial prenatal care visit.  She has had no headaches, chest pain, abdominal pain, or lower extremity swelling.  Medical history is significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus managed with multiple daily insulin injections.  Blood pressure is 144/88 mm Hg and pulse is 86/min.  Cardiopulmonary examination is normal.  Fetal heart tones are 152/min on Doppler ultrasonography.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin12.1 g/dL
    Platelets168,000/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Potassium4.3 mEq/L
    Creatinine1.4 mg/dL (baseline a year ago: 1.1)
    Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)12 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)14 U/L

Urinalysis reveals 2+ protein but no red or white blood cells.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's proteinuria?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus has proteinuria and an elevated creatinine level at 10 weeks gestation; this presentation suggests diabetic kidney disease (DKD).  The development of significant proteinuria (>300 mg/24 hr, ≥1-2+ protein) prior to 20 weeks gestation suggests underlying kidney disease that was likely present before conception.  In DKD, chronic hyperglycemia causes dilation of renal afferent arterioles and constriction of efferent arterioles, resulting in glomerular hyperfiltration.  Structural and functional changes in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and podocytes lead to loss of albumin in the urine (microalbuminuria).

During normal pregnancy, renal perfusion and glomerular filtration rates increase by as much as 50%, and the GBM becomes more permeable to proteins.  Therefore, patients with DKD are at risk for acceleration of kidney disease during pregnancy (worsening albuminuria, elevated creatinine) due to the combined effects on the kidney.  This risk is particularly high in those with an elevated creatinine at baseline.  Hypertension is a common complication of DKD due to excess sodium retention and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

(Choice B)  Gestational hypertension causes new-onset hypertension but not proteinuria; it occurs exclusively at ≥20 weeks gestation.

(Choice C)  Normal pregnancy can cause trace proteinuria, but creatinine is expected to decline, not increase (usually <0.4-0.9 mg/dL).  In addition, blood pressure typically declines in early pregnancy; the presence of hypertension indicates underlying pathology.

(Choice D)  Preeclampsia with severe features causes new-onset hypertension and proteinuria but is extremely rare at <20 weeks gestation.  This is because pathogenesis involves abnormal placental pathology, which becomes progressively worse as the pregnancy advances.  It may also be accompanied by evidence of end-organ dysfunction (eg, elevated transaminases, thrombocytopenia).

(Choice E)  Renal artery stenosis due to fibromuscular dysplasia is a rare cause of hypertension in women of childbearing age but typically does not result in acute kidney injury unless ACE inhibitors or diuretics are administered; marked proteinuria is uncommon.

Educational objective:
Pregnancy can worsen diabetic kidney disease, leading to hypertension, elevated creatinine, and frank proteinuria.  Preeclampsia also causes hypertension and proteinuria but occurs later in pregnancy; findings prior to 20 weeks gestation are usually due to preexisting nephropathy.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Diabetic kidney disease

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Pregnancy in women with diabetic nephropathy.
Diabetic nephropathy in women with preexisting diabetes: from pregnancy planning to breastfeeding.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to progressively worsening lower extremity edema.  He has exertional dyspnea but no orthopnea.  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min.  BMI is 52 kg/m2.  Cardiac examination shows normal rhythm and no murmurs or gallops.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  There is no jugular venous distension.  The abdomen is large and soft.  There is 2+ pitting edema in both feet.  Serum creatinine is 1.7 mg/dL.  Urinalysis shows 4+ protein but is otherwise normal.  A 24-hour urine test shows protein excretion of 5 g.  Kidney biopsy is obtained; 10% of the examined glomeruli have global sclerosis, and another 10% have partial sclerosis in the perihilar region.  Nonsclerotic glomeruli exhibit slight enlargement without significant proliferative changes.  Immunofluorescence study shows no deposition of immunoreactants.  Electron microscopy shows 40% foot process effacement.  HIV testing is negative.  Which of the following would most likely slow progression of this patient's renal dysfunction?
questionList.explanationText:
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

Pathogenesis

  • Primary FSGS: circulating factor causing immune injury to podocytes
  • Secondary FSGS: glomerular hyperfiltration (eg, obesity, solitary kidney, reflux nephropathy), podocyte toxin (eg, heroin), infection (eg, HIVAN)

Clinical features

  • Primary FSGS: usually nephrotic syndrome
  • Secondary FSGS: proteinuria ± nephrotic syndrome

Diagnosis

  • LM: segmental scarring in <50% of glomeruli*
  • IF: usually negative
  • EM: podocyte foot process effacement**

Treatment

  • Renin-angiotensin blockade, loop diuretics
  • Primary FSGS: immunosuppression
  • Secondary FSGS: risk factor modification (eg, weight loss, ART)

*Glomerular tuft collapse is also seen in HIVAN.

**Diffuse (≥80%) effacement in primary; segmental (<80%) effacement in secondary.

ART = antiretroviral therapy; EM = electron microscopy; FSGS = focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; HIVAN = HIV-associated nephropathy; IF = immunofluorescence microscopy; LM = light microscopy.

This patient's kidney biopsy finding of glomerular scarring (ie, sclerosis) affecting only some glomeruli (focal) in parts (segmental) is consistent with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).  FSGS results from podocyte (visceral epithelial cell) injury, seen as foot process effacement on electron microscopy; loss of the filtration barrier usually causes nephrotic syndrome (peripheral edema, proteinuria >3.5 g/day).  In contrast to pediatric patients in whom FSGS may be genetic (eg, podocin mutation), FSGS in adults is classified by the cause of podocyte injury as follows:

  • Primary FSGS:  A circulating factor causes podocyte injury, resulting in kidney dysfunction and nephrotic syndrome.  Although it is believed to be immune mediated, immunofluorescence is typically negative.

  • Secondary FSGS:  Podocyte injury results from glomerular hyperfiltration (eg, severe obesity, solitary kidney), toxins (eg, heroin), or infection (eg, HIV) causing kidney dysfunction and proteinuria that may or may not reach nephrotic range.

Management of secondary FSGS involves addressing the underlying cause.  Patients with severe obesity (BMI of 52 kg/m2 in this patient) benefit from weight loss to lessen hyperfiltration injury from podocyte shear stress, thereby reducing proteinuria and slowing progression of renal dysfunction.  Supportive care with renin-angiotensin blockade (eg, ACE inhibitors) to reduce proteinuria and loop diuretics to control edema is indicated.  Immunosuppressants (eg, corticosteroids) are typically not beneficial in secondary FSGS, although they are used in primary (ie, immune-mediated) FSGS (Choice C).

(Choice A)  Antibiotics are used in glomerular diseases caused by bacterial infections, such as nephrotic syndrome from syphilis-induced membranous nephropathy and nephritic syndrome from postinfectious glomerulonephritis.  However, antibiotics are not helpful in FSGS because it is not caused by bacterial infections.

(Choice B)  Antiviral medications are indicated when FSGS is caused by a viral infection.  Although HIV is a common cause of FSGS, this patient has a negative HIV test and has no signs or symptoms of other viral infections (eg, cytomegalovirus).  Hepatitis C virus infection can cause glomerulopathies, but it is most commonly associated with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis rather than FSGS.  This patient's BMI and biopsy findings are most consistent with secondary FSGS.

(Choice D)  Although thiazide diuretics are effective antihypertensives, they are less effective for edema than loop diuretics.  Notably, loop diuretics do not reduce proteinuria or slow the progression of renal dysfunction in patients with FSGS.

Educational objective:
Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by podocyte injury due to a variety of causes (eg, severe obesity).  Patients with severe obesity benefit from weight loss to lessen hyperfiltration injury from podocyte shear stress, thereby reducing proteinuria and slowing progression of renal dysfunction.

questionList.questionText:
A 60-year-old man is hospitalized with multiple generalized tonic-clonic seizures.  The patient is a heavy alcohol user and has had previous hospitalizations for alcohol withdrawal and alcohol-related seizures.  On the second day of hospitalization, temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 155/92 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Examination shows no abnormalities.  Laboratory studies are shown below:

Serum chemistry
    Sodium140 mEq/L
    Potassium5.6 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate20 mEq/L
    Blood urea nitrogen36 mg/dL
    Creatinine2.4 mg/dL
Urinalysis
    Glucosenegative
    Ketonestrace
    Leukocyte esterasenegative
    Blood2+

Urine microscopy shows white blood cells 2-5/hpf, red blood cells 0-1/hpf, and some epithelial cells.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's renal dysfunction?
questionList.explanationText:
Rhabdomyolysis

Etiology

Skeletal muscle lysis/necrosis due to:

  • Crush injury or prolonged immobilization
  • Intense muscle activity (eg, seizure, exertion)
  • Drug/medication toxicity (eg, statins)

Clinical features

  • Muscle pain & weakness
  • Dark urine (myoglobinuria/pigmenturia)
  • + Blood on urinalysis & no RBCs on microscopy
  • ↑ Serum K & PO4, ↓ serum Ca, ↑ AST > ALT
  • Acute kidney injury

Diagnosis

  • Serum creatine kinase >1,000 U/L
  • Consistent clinical features

Management

  • Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation
  • Sodium bicarbonate in some cases

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; RBCs = red blood cells.

This patient with renal insufficiency and discordant blood findings on urine testing (eg, positive blood on urinalysis with negative red blood cells [RBCs] on urine microscopy) following recent tonic-clonic seizures likely has rhabdomyolysis.  Rhabdomyolysis involves large-scale skeletal muscle necrosis that can result from crush injury, ischemia, direct toxicity, or in the case of seizures, overexertion from intense and prolonged muscle contraction.

A key component of rhabdomyolysis is the release of myoglobin, a skeletal muscle O2-storage protein that contains heme pigment, into the bloodstream.  In the kidneys, myoglobin is degraded and releases heme into the renal tubules; this can cause renal tubular obstruction and tubular epithelial cell injury, resulting in acute tubular necrosis (eg, renal insufficiency).  Potassium and phosphorus are also released from lysed muscle cells, causing hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.

Discordance between urinalysis (rapid dipstick) and urine microscopy blood findings is useful in recognizing rhabdomyolysis.  The blood component of urinalysis detects heme rather than actual RBCs.  Therefore, myoglobinuria due to rhabdomyolysis leads to positive blood on urinalysis (due to the presence of heme from myoglobin degradation) in the absence of RBCs on urine microscopy; by contrast, true hematuria leads to positive blood on urinalysis and presence of RBCs on urine microscopy.

(Choice A)  Acute interstitial nephritis involves renal inflammation, typically evidenced by positive leukocyte esterase on urinalysis and elevated white blood cells (WBCs) with WBC casts on urine microscopy.  This patient's urine WBCs are within normal limits.

(Choice B)  Glomerulonephritis is characterized by RBCs passing through the glomerular membrane to cause true hematuria; dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts are expected on urine microscopy.

(Choice C)  Hepatorenal syndrome can occur in patients with advanced liver disease.  It results from vasoconstriction of renal arterioles, causing prerenal injury with an expected blood urea nitrogen/creatinine ratio >20.  Positive blood is not expected on urinalysis.

(Choice D)  Nephrolithiasis is a common cause of true hematuria; in addition to positive blood on urinalysis, numerous RBCs are expected on urine microscopy.

(Choices E and G)  Both urinary tract obstruction (eg, benign prostatic hyperplasia) and renal artery stenosis can cause renal insufficiency; however, rhabdomyolysis is much more likely in this patient given his recent seizure and discordant blood findings on urine testing (which would not been seen with urinary tract obstruction or renal artery stenosis).

Educational objective:
Skeletal muscle overexertion (eg, due to tonic-clonic seizure) is a potential cause of rhabdomyolysis, which involves the release of myoglobin into the bloodstream and may cause heme-induced acute renal insufficiency.  Because urinalysis blood testing detects heme rather than actual red blood cells (RBCs), rhabdomyolysis is often suggested by positive blood on urinalysis in the absence of RBCs on urine microscopy.

questionList.questionText:
A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to intermittent severe right flank pain over the past few days.  He has had decreased urination over the last week but has also noted occasional episodes of high urine output along with a feeling of generalized weakness.  The patient has a history of chronic back pain for which he takes oxycodone daily, and he underwent a left total nephrectomy following a motor vehicle accident 25 years ago.  He was recently started on low-dose lisinopril for a new diagnosis of hypertension.  There is no family history of renal disease.  On physical examination, blood pressure is 145/86 mm Hg and heart rate is 86/min.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
    Potassium3.4 mEq/L
    Creatinine1.7 mg/dL
Urinalysis
    Proteintrace
    White blood cells4/hpf
    Red blood cells2/hpf
    Castsnone

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with a history of total nephrectomy now most likely has unilateral obstructive uropathy due to renal calculi.  Symptoms that support this diagnosis include flank pain (renal capsular distension) and poor urine output (mechanical obstruction to urine outflow).  Intermittent episodes of high-volume urination can occur when the obstruction is overcome by a large volume of retained urine (post-obstructive diuresis).  Excessive diuresis may lead to potassium wasting and dehydration, both of which can cause weakness.

Post-obstructive diuresis may be seen in patients with bilateral functional kidneys as the affected kidney will produce a large volume of urine when the obstruction is relieved.  However, patients with a single kidney are more likely to develop acute renal failure than are those with both kidneys intact.

(Choice A)  Most adrenal tumors are benign and asymptomatic.  Symptoms of hormone-producing adrenal tumors depend on the hormone being secreted.  Nonfunctioning adrenal carcinomas may present with flank pain due to tumor growth.  However, symptoms are less severe, and no change in urinary output would be expected.

(Choice B)  Glomerulonephritis presents with hematuria, red blood cell casts, acute renal failure, hypertension, and edema.

(Choice C)  The leading cause of inherited renal disease is autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.  Patients typically present with persistent abdominal or flank pain and hematuria, which may be gross or microscopic (>3 red blood cells/hpf).  There is a positive family history in 75% of cases.  Over half of patients have hypertension at presentation.

(Choice D)  Interstitial nephritis most frequently occurs as a drug reaction.  Patients present with fever, rash, acute kidney injury, and eosinophiluria with white blood cell casts.

(Choice E)  Renal artery stenosis can cause hypertension with or without kidney injury.  It does not cause flank pain or urinary symptoms.

Educational objective:
Obstructive uropathy presents with flank pain, low-volume voids with or without occasional high-volume voids, and, if bilateral, renal dysfunction.
